thread.title: Virat Kohli focussed on next target: 'Our minds and hearts on Australia series' : Cricket, News - India Today
thread.title_full: Virat Kohli focussed on next target: 'Our minds and hearts on Australia series' : Cricket, News - India Today

title: Virat Kohli focussed on next target: 'Our minds and hearts on Australia series' : Cricket, News - India Today
text:
This is India's sixth consecutive Test series win 2 India beat New Zealand and England before this at home 3 The four-match Test series versus Australia starts from February 23 
Virat Kohli and Team India are on a roll. They have steamrolled New Zealand, England and Bangladesh in a dominant home season and the captain has led from the front with three double hundreds, a sensational 167 and two half-centuries. 
Kohli was in his elements in Hyderabad in the one-off Test against Bangladesh. First, he blasted an aggressive double hundred, his fourth this season. Then his shrewd tactics allowed India to fight their way to a crushing 208-run win over the hapless visitors on a flat pitch. ( Also read: Virat Kohli called for a review even after third umpire said "NOT OUT". And India won ) 
But the 28-year-old, who is now India's third-most successful Test captain with 15 wins from 23 matches, is in no mood to enjoy these milestones. Kohli and his men are already focussed on the four-Test series against Australia which gets underway in Pune from February 23. 
"I thought England was the biggest series for us this season, but having won that 4-0, we want to consolidate on that against Australia. ( Also read: Stats: Virat Kohli most successful Indian captain after the first 23 Tests ) 
"Everyone's minds and hearts are already on it," Kohli said at the post-match presentation ceremony, where he picked the man-of-the-match award. 
Kohli has enjoyed his rivalry with Australia over the years. His first Test hundred had come against the Aussies in 2012 after he had copped some serious sledging from the hosts right through the series. ( Also read: Virat Kohli breaches 1000-run mark in home Tests this season ) 
In 2014-15, Kohli, in his first Test as captain, struck twin hundreds in Adelaide to take India close to an improbable win. He hammered two more hundreds in the same series and finished with 692 runs from four Tests. 
There is plenty of talk in the Australian captain about how to deal with Kohli. While coach Darren Lehmann admitted his team was yet to finalise on plans to stop the Indian run-machine, skipper Steve Smith felt it might be a good idea to make his Indian counterpart angry. 
However, former Australian batsman Michael Hussey said Smith's men should avoid engaging in verbal battles with Kohli as he thrives on those situations.Virat Kohli and Team India are on a roll. They have steamrolled New Zealand, England and Bangladesh in a dominant home season and the captain has led from the front with three double hundreds, a sensational 167 and two half-centuries. 
Kohli was in his elements in Hyderabad in the one-off Test against Bangladesh. First, he blasted an aggressive double hundred, his fourth this season. Then his shrewd tactics allowed India to fight their way to a crushing 208-run win over the hapless visitors on a flat pitch. 
But the 28-year-old, who is now India's third-most successful Test captain with 15 wins from 23 matches, is in no mood to enjoy these milestones. Kohli and his men are already focussed on the four-Test series against Australia which gets underway in Pune from February 23. 
"I thought England was the biggest series for us this season, but having won that 4-0, we want to consolidate on that against Australia. 
"Everyone's minds and hearts are already on it," Kohli said at the post-match presentation ceremony, where he picked the man-of-the-match award. 
Kohli has enjoyed his rivalry with Australia over the years. His first Test hundred had come against the Aussies in 2012 after he had copped some serious sledging from the hosts right through the series. 
In 2014-15, Kohli, in his first Test as captain, struck twin hundreds in Adelaide to take India close to an improbable win. He hammered two more hundreds in the same series and finished with 692 runs from four Tests. 
There is plenty of talk in the Australian captain about how to deal with Kohli. While coach Darren Lehmann admitted his team was yet to finalise on plans to stop the Indian run-machine, skipper Steve Smith felt it might be a good idea to make his Indian counterpart angry. 
However, former Australian batsman Michael Hussey said Smith's men should avoid engaging in verbal battles with Kohli as he thrives on those situations.
